One of my friends suggested that torch flowers could light up/glow brighter with movement, so they would emit light as the player walks past

Torch Flowers should not just be a light source, they should be a triggerable light source, offering a sorely needed alternative to glowstone lamps.

The light should be dependent on the flower being on irrigated farmland. That way, you could control it with redstone, via a water dispenser! It would have the unique property of having a random time delay before turning on/off, due to the time it takes for farmland to change. 

Imagine putting fields of torch flowers in the floor of your base, covered by glass blocks or carpets, or having rows of them in the walls. You flick the light switch, and the lights slowly come on. Or just as a really pretty way to light up your produce farms. Related niche use: would also make irrigation mess-ups in your farms noticeable from a distance.

We're not exactly suffering a great shortage of decorative flowers anymore, but this would make them very unique and desirable, offering great motivation for players to actually bother with archeology and the sniffer to get them.

Silverfish's role in the game is based on real life mice/rats (which is as the pest that can hide in the walls)
Mice/rats would be interesting if they:
1. were much larger than their real life equivalent
2. tampered with blocks somehow (like stripping logs)
3. were neutral like zombified piglins (if you attack one, prepare to be swarmed)
4. lived in large colonies in a mousehole block (like a beehive)

though they would be awfully similar to bees...

I think it would be an amazing feature to build into what little history Minecraft has. It also would be an amazing way to build on different ways to add more diverse mobs. basing them on real prehistoric animals, or it could add more imaginative mobs using it to create mobs like the blaze, creeper, and guardian.
I think that certain structures currently in the game should be transformed into dig sites. It would be a lot of effort, but I think it'd be worth it.

Neat idea, but what would this raid boss actually be?

I'm thinking something of a pillager raid master, an exceptionally experienced and respected veteran of the illagers, equipped with both a vindicator's axe and a pillager's crossbow, as well as a set of goat horns to call in small groups of reinforcements. He would need quite a bit of complex ai to run give players a proper challenge of skill rather than just the clash of big numbers most pve engagements tend to be, focussing on hit and run tactics, as he needs distance for his entire support arsenal, while the most immediate threat is his axe. Reloads and blowing horns would both be openings the player could take and with some particularly advanced ai could also be completely disrupted by persistently staying aggressive, as he would see himself forced to change priorities mid action and emergency switch to his axe instead.

For his goat horns, different horn sounds are different signals for different enemy groups, thereby telegraphing what you are about to be flanked by, if he gets to blow it. None of these groups should be devastating on their own, but engaging in a sniper duel with him should be a surefire way to get utterly overwhelmed by the reinforcements unless you built up some proper raid defenses beforehand.

Maybe he could trade you maps to find more sites.

My idea: Archaeologist villagers don't spawn naturally, you need to craft their working station.

This working station is crafted with materials you find in the new Trail Ruins

The archaeologist villager can be used to get armor trims, maps to archaeology sites, suspicious sand and gravel with random loot, and maybe even Netherite Upgrade smithing templates, being an safer alternative to bastions (think about how important mending villagers are, archaeologists should be something like that).

However, the working station is difficult to obtain, since its materials are a rare find.

The Archeology Villager could also have a few contrasting traits from that of other villagers. I say this because if he is at the Archeology site, he could be a bit more related to the ancestors of the ancient trails. Much like how the Wandering Trader has a different texture and carries 2 llamas by a lead!

Also, the pottery shard labeled, "Friend Pottery Shard" (clearly a villager) could be what this villager 10% looks like! For example:

-A larger unibrow

-Has a bit of hair? It is a bit of a reach honestly, but it would be very defined as no other villagers have this trait. 

The normal traits of the villager would be very important to the theme of Tales and Trails as he would have a sachel filled with pottery shards, armor trims, and a rolled-up map. Also, the person in the comment section with the Archeology bench idea? Absolutely genius! You are what Minecraft needs for updates!  Another idea that might be a slight reach, although not as much as the hair, but an ancient book traded by the Archeology Villager written by the ancestors that might give clues about the construction of the trails, ancient cities being related, etc.

When a new update comes out, there could also be more shards added, probably 2 each, to add to what the ancestors had and maybe some things that show imminent doom from the depths of the warden. 

Thanks for Listening! Warm regards,

TB
